column4: does anyone know of a way to convert a 32bit ubutnu install to a 64bit install?
what about installing over my current install?
I went the other way (64 bit to 32 bit) and the only solution I found was to install from scratch.
that I can understand.
may I ask why you went from 64 back to 32 bit?

it was fiesty at the time, but I found lots of problems with 64 bit on the desktop, mainly having to do with things such as flash and java being a pita to get working, plus not being able to use w32codecs for videos, etc.
ahh okies.. yea this will be a backend server. no gui stuff needed ;)
ahhh, ok, I do run some centos servers as 64 bit and I have no problems with that.  My feelings is that 64 bit is good for the server but not for the desktop.
not until some of the more commanly used things are moved to 64bit like java and flash
exactly

I tried that, but I found that the pain of getting 32 bit things to work on a setup like that was not outweighed by the performance differences of 64 bit vs 32 bit.  I just run 32 bit now and everything works painlessly.
for me it works well with gentoo. but then everything is pretty much compiled as 64bit
yes, I can see that it would work better with gentoo sinc eyou can control the compilation of everything.
yep. I once I get my server in my noc at work, I will help with developmenting and making 64bit packages for ubuntu
yep, the 64 bit packaging in ubuntu is largely good, though.  The main problems is with proprietary stuff that you can't get source code on.
very true. that is mostly were the world would be needed
